channel.title: Merged Defense / NATO / SpaceWar Feed
channel.description: Aggregated RSS feed from NATO, DefenseOne, and SpaceWar

item.title: Inside Europe's crash effort to create a 'drone wall'
item.description: More sensors, more maneuverable, less expensive: How the Ukraine war is shaping the future of drone air defense.

item.title: The D Brief: Trump declares war on cartels; Feds storm Chicago apartments; Europe’s ‘drone wall’; Shadow economies; And a bit more.
Shutdown poised to drag into next week as layoff threat looms
item.description: Senate once again fails to approve spending bill and the two sides remain far divided.

item.title: NGA wants to put its idle PCs to work
item.description: GDIT is networking the agency’s St. Louis workstations to crunch geospatial data even when analysts aren’t around.

item.title: The D Brief: Guard deployments on hold; 4th speedboat bombed; Russia strikes Lviv; China’s black-market oil; And a bit more.
Venezuela, US edge toward war footing—but the White House may blink first
item.description: The Trump administration is increasing the pressure, but domestic concerns, international risks may hold it back.

item.title: Hamas has run out of options
item.description: The group's survival now rests on accepting Trump’s plan and political reform.

item.title: More employees set to receive furlough notices as shutdown drags on
item.description: DOD has not said how long nonexempt civilian employees might be kept working.

item.title: Flood of questions leads Missile Defense Agency to push Golden Dome deadline one week
item.description: Pitches for a slice of MDA’s 10-year, up-to-$151 billion contract vehicle are now due Oct. 16.

item.title: OMB quietly deletes reference to law requiring back pay to furloughed feds
item.description: A White House FAQ now says restitution is only guaranteed to excepted employees forced to work without pay.

item.title: The D Brief: Troops to Chicago; Trump’s partisan speech to sailors; F/A-XX OK?; MDA’s big Golden Dome vehicle; And a bit more.
Denied in July, DHS intelligence office resumes efforts to shed staff
item.description: After stakeholders scuttled dramatic cuts, the Office of Intelligence and Analysis is quietly offering buyouts instead.

item.title: Skeptical senators grill White House pick to lead Indo-Pacific policy
item.description: The nominee to be assistant defense secretary for Indo-Pacific security affairs, backed the president's push for Taiwan to spend more.

item.title: Federal shutdown deals blow to already-hobbled cybersecurity agency
item.description: Two-thirds of the staff at the nation’s cybersecurity agency are sidelined, opening opportunities for malicious hackers.

item.title: The D Brief: Senators doubt Asia policy; Jail Illinois leaders, says POTUS; Civil-military ‘crisis’; DHS cuts intel staff; And a bit more.
It’s time to return Turkey to the F-35 fold, even if we have to get creative
item.description: It's a sticking point that is blocking deeper US-NATO-Turkish defense cooperation.

item.title: Legal experts fear Trump admin is ignoring JAGs on cartel strikes, Guard deployments
item.description: A former military lawyer and a former judge encouraged commanders to stand up to unlawful orders.

item.title: Lawmakers call for more defense biotech research as China pursues breakthroughs
item.description: Shelf-stable blood, biological camouflage, and biosensors are just some of the potential innovations.

item.title: ‘Stop trying to control every step’ of shipbuilding, senator tells Navy
item.description: Focus less on requirements and more on outcomes, says Montana’s Sheehy, and the entire Pentagon might get on board.

item.title: DHS tells hundreds of staffers: accept reassignment to border security, immigration—or face termination
item.description: The affected workers including some at CISA, FEMA, and the Coast Guard. Some have been given a week to respond.

item.title: The D Brief: Ceasefire near in Gaza?; Troops arrive in Chicago; Shipbuilding advice; Deportation stats; And a bit more.
Get more F-35s in the air and don't break the bank, senators beg USAF chief nominee
item.description: Gen. Wilsbach declined to endorse the service’s ongoing reorganization to counter China.

item.title: Current, former state leaders weigh in on Trump’s deployment of National Guard troops
item.description: In legal briefs, 17 current Republican attorneys general support the president, while a bipartisan group of former governors objects.

item.title: Amid shutdown, the Army will do its best to talk transformation, counter-drones, and acquisition reform
item.description: AUSA annual meeting to feature a rare public discussion of Pentagon’s new homeland focus.

item.title: Space Systems Command adds second Blue Origin deal to boost vehicle processing at Cape Canaveral
item.description:
El Segundo CA (SPX) Oct 09, 2025
Space Systems Command is expanding its space vehicle processing capacity at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station by 2028, awarding Blue Origin a $78.25 million contract. The award is the second National Security Space Launch Space Vehicle Processing Commercial Solutions Opening contract aimed at strengthening responsive and resilient launch operations. "This second CSO award reflects our con

item.title: NATO drone competition highlightes use of autonomous technology in disaster relief
item.description:
Huntsville AL (SPX) Sep 30, 2025
This summer, The University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH), a part of The University of Alabama System, hosted the SAPIENCE Drone Competition, an international Unmanned Aircraft System (UAS) event supported by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Science for Peace and Security Programme. SAPIENCE stands for "Sense and Avoid - a cooPeratIvE droNe CompEtition," a project that highlights t

item.title: Trump unlikely to win Nobel Peace Prize, but who will?
item.description:
Oslo (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
When it comes to this year's Nobel Peace Prize, one thing is almost certain: US President Donald Trump will not win, no matter how much he wants it. But who will? The Norwegian Nobel Committee in Oslo will bring the suspense to an end when it announces the winner Friday at 11:00 am (0900 GMT). The backdrop is bleak: the number of armed conflicts worldwide involving at least one state has

item.title: Dutch NGO rejects Burkina junta's claims of spying
item.description:
Abidjan (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
An NGO on Wednesday denied claims by the Burkina Faso authorities that its workers had been involved in spying a day after the military regime arrested more of its staff. The International and Safety Organisation (INSO) was responding a day after the country's Security Minister Mahamadou Sana accused its staff of "spying and treason". "We categorically reject the allegations made regardi

item.title: Japan's Takaichi may skip visit to Tokyo war shrine: reports
item.description:
Tokyo (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
Japan's likely new prime minister Sanae Takaichi may skip visiting a shrine honouring war dead this month to avoid angering Asian neighbours, media reports said. Past visits by senior politicians to Yasukuni - which honours even convicted war criminals - have angered China and South Korea. The conservative Takaichi, who on Saturday became leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (

item.title: EU wants key sectors to use made-in-Europe AI
item.description:
Strasbourg, France (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
The EU on Wednesday told European businesses in critical sectors to ramp up their uptake of artificial intelligence and pushed for the bloc to cut its dependence on foreign AI providers. Although the European Union is falling behind the United States and China, Brussels believes the bloc can still compete in the global AI race. To achieve this, the European Commission said it was mobilis

item.title: EU 'must respond' to Russia's 'hybrid warfare': von der Leyen
item.description:
Strasbourg, France Oct 8, 2025
EU chief Ursula von der Leyen on Wednesday said Europe must ramp up its defences to deter Russia's "hybrid warfare", after a catalogue of air incursions, cyber attacks and damage to undersea cables. "These incidents are calculated to linger in the twilight of deniability. This is not random harassment. It is a coherent and escalating campaign," the European Commission head said in a speech t

item.title: China sanctions 14 foreign firms over Taiwan ties, national security
item.description:
Beijing (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
Beijing sanctioned on Thursday 14 overseas entities, including defence contractors and intelligence firms, accusing them of harming national security and aiding Taiwan. Several American defence contractors, British aerospace giant BAE Systems and Canada-based semiconductor intelligence provider TechInsights - and its affiliates in Europe, Japan and South Korea - were among the firms added

item.title: Belgium says foiled jihadist plot for drone attack on politicians
item.description:
Brussels, Belgium (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
Belgian authorities said Thursday they had arrested three young adults for plotting a jihadist-inspired attack using drone-mounted explosives, with Prime Minister Bart De Wever reported to be among several politicians targeted. The arrests were made in the northern city of Antwerp as part of an investigation into "attempted terrorist murder and participation in the activities of a terrorist

item.title: US hits Iraq's Olympic Committee president in fresh Iran-related sanctions
item.description:
Washington (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
The US Treasury on Thursday ramped up its Iran-related sanctions, targeting a firm with ties to Iran-backed militia groups in Iraq, and the president of the Iraq's Olympic Committee. In a statement, the Treasury Department accused these militia of helping "the Iranian regime in evading U.S. sanctions, smuggling weapons, and engaging in widespread corruption in Iraq," and of being responsibl

item.title: North Korea's Kim hails 'cooperative' ties with China
item.description:
Seoul (AFP) Oct 10, 2025
North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un hailed "friendly and cooperative" ties with China as he hosted Premier Li Qiang and other foreign dignitaries for celebrations marking 80 years under the ruling Workers' Party, state media reported Friday. China is North Korea's most important ally, although relations have at times been strained by Pyongyang's nuclear programme. North Korea is expected to

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize to be announced as Trump pines for it
item.description:
Oslo (AFP) Oct 10, 2025
The Nobel Peace Prize will be announced on Friday, a day after a Gaza deal likely reached too late for US President Donald Trump to have any chance to win the award he desperately wants. The Norwegian Nobel Committee will announce the recipient of the Peace Prize, the most highly anticipated of the prestigious Nobels, at 11:00 am (0900 GMT) in the capital Oslo. The announcement is due ju

item.title: Trump says 'stepping up pressure' to end Ukraine war
item.description:
Washington (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
US President Donald Trump said Thursday that Washington and NATO allies were "stepping up the pressure" to end the war in Ukraine, after his outreach to Russia's Vladimir Putin failed to achieve a ceasefire. "Yeah, we are stepping up the pressure," Trump said in the Oval Office during a meeting with Finnish President Alexander Stubb when asked by an AFP reporter if he would increase efforts

item.title: Team of 200 US troops to 'oversee' Gaza truce: US officials
item.description:
Washington (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
A US military team of 200 people will be deployed in the Middle East to "oversee" the Gaza ceasefire between Israel and Hamas after a peace deal brokered by President Donald Trump, senior US officials said Thursday. Admiral Brad Cooper, the head of the US military's Central Command, "will initially have 200 people on the ground. His role will be to oversee, observe, make sure there are no vi

item.title: Trump suggests Spain be expelled from NATO over low defense spending
item.description:
Washington (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
President Donald Trump suggested Thursday that Spain be expelled from NATO over its failure to match the higher defense spending requirement he has engineered. "We had one laggard, it was Spain," Trump told reporters in the Oval Office. "They have no excuse not to do this, but that's all right. Maybe you should throw them out of NATO frankly." In June, the 32-nation North Atlantic Treaty
